Problem:
Consider a function \\( f(z) = \\int_0^{\\infty} e^{-st} z(t) dt \\) where \\( z(t) \\) is a complex-valued function and \\( s \\) is a complex parameter. Analyze the causal influences when we alter \\( z(t) \\) by a multiplier \\( e^{i\\omega t} \\) where \\( \\omega \\) is a real constant.

If an initial function \\( z(t) \\) is modified to \\( e^{i\\omega t} z(t) \\) at t = 0 and evolves under the defined integral transformation without further modification, will the transform \\( f(z) \\) be the same as it was before modifying \\( z(t) \\)?
Explanation: Modifying \\( z(t) \\) by multiplying it with \\( e^{i\\omega t} \\) shifts the frequency components of \\( z(t) \\) by \\( \\omega \\) in the Laplace domain. This frequency shift translates to a modification in the value of \\( s \\) to \\( s-i\\omega \\) in the integral expression of \\( f(z) \\), leading to a different outcome of the integral.
